text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with chicago Italian view sandwich
stew meat edition that's right instead
of using thinly sliced roast beef I
desecrated this classic Midwest sandwich
by using stew beef which may or may not
have been a good idea although one thing
I do know for sure if you're around
people from Chicago and they're watching
this with you they will not like this
just on principle but anyway we're not
going to let that stop us
and we're going to move on to the first
step which is prepping the beef or as
they say in Chicago dubbed beef it's
right here I have about a pound and a
half of beef stew meat that is beef
chuck and we're going to go ahead and
season that up with some salt and pepper
and by the way I just bought a piece of
beef chuck and cut it up like that
myself to save money but if you want to
spend more and get a lower quality meat
just go ahead and buy the pre-cut stew
meat at the butcher counter oh they love
when you do that but I do recommend
cutting your own once we have that
seasoned we're going to go ahead and
sear that on high heat and a little bit
of vegetable oil and some kind of
heavy-duty pot or pan it has a lid and
like you said we're gonna Brown this
meat fairly well over high heat and once
we have that fairly well browned we'll
go ahead and add a whole bunch of garlic
and spices and herbs along with a little
broth and what we'll do is we'll just
simply stew this until the beef is
tender and that's pretty much it so once
our meats brown we're going to go ahead
and add a whole bunch of sliced garlic
we're gonna want a nice big pinch of red
pepper flakes some more freshly ground
black pepper some dry oregano some dry
thyme some dry rosemary we're gonna need
some more salt we're going to throw in a
bay leaf and then for the wet
ingredients I'm going to put in a little
bit of white wine vinegar a lot of
people like to use a splash of wine in
here but I like the vinegar and then
we're going to go ahead and add enough
chicken stock or chicken broth to cover
and then all we're going to do is bring
this up to a simmer reduce the heat and
stew it until it's tender so in the
original recipe they'll make a roast
beef slice it thin and add that back
into the natural beef juices that they
make with the roasting pan which is very
delicious but here I was thinking let's
take some stew beef and cook it right in
that flavorful broth and save a step so
that's the plan at least so we're gonna
do a standard student technique here you
go ahead and leave your heat on high
until it starts to bubble and of course
we're gonna back that heat down to low
until we have a nice steady but very
very gentle simmer at that point we're
simply going to cover
it and cook that for about an hour to an
hour and a half or until those chunks of
meat are fork tender oh by the way
people think I'm cool check out the
socks and sandals combo oh yeah that's
good look anyway like I said we're going
to let that simmer slowly until it's
fork-tender so when you think you're
getting close done cover it and the best
instrument for testing for fork
tenderness is a fork so I did a little
test and I determined yes my meat is
fork tender and at that point we're
ready to divide and conquer
so I'm going to take a strainer I'm
going to separate the meat into a
separate pot along with a little bit of
the juice and I'm going to take a wooden
spoon and I'm just going to break it up
a little I don't want this shredded like
a pulled pork sandwich which by the way
was also one of the inspirations for
this recipe but I do want to break it up
a little bit so it's easier to portion
onto the rolls so I'm going to work that
over with a wooden spoon for a few
seconds and again we're going to want a
splash in enough juice to keep it very
moist at that point we're just going to
cover that and keep it warm until we're
ready to build our sandwiches okay so
our meats ready we're just going to
reserve that until needed and it's on to
the final two phases the juice and the
vegetables and for the juicers really
not much to do you can skim off some fat
if you want I did a little bit and
you're going to give that a taste and it
should be very very strongly flavored
like spicy salty and very Irby but
that's how it's supposed to be this is
not a soup we're gonna use that to soak
our bread and to dip the sandwich into
so you want it strongly flavored and you
could strain this if you want but I'm
not going to I'm just going to keep it
hot like the beef until I'm ready to
serve so that's all set and we're onto
the last and final ingredient the Jardin
era or Jardin error depends on what part
of Chicago you're from and all this is
is an Italian combination of mixed
pickled vegetables and all we're going
to do here is chop that up into a relish
we're going to use that to top our
sandwich and it is going to be fantastic
and of course we should have made that
homemade but in fairness the Italian
beef sandwiches I've had in Chicago
actually came topped with jar-jar naira
so I think I'm okay here and once our
Jardin area is chopped we are ready to
build our sandwiches so step one you
want to cut open some kind of crusty
roll you're going to want to drench it
liberally with that garlicky spicy
Irby broth I would go pretty much full
saturation and that's why you want to
use something very crusty do not try
this with white bread please it will not
end well so pretty much full saturation
next up we're going to top with a big
spoon of that beautiful tender aromatic
delicious pea
and yes a piece did fall on the floor
thank you for asking but the show must
go on
and once we've laid down a slightly too
generous portion of beef we're going to
top with an equally generous spoon of
our pickled vegetables and that beef
stew version of Chicago Italian beef
sandwich is done so let's go ahead and
cut that in half because this needs to
be Dibble so make sure you cut it
diagonally that'll make it easier to dip
and as you know people love pointy food
so we're going to throw that on a plate
with a ramekin of piping hot stewing
liquid beef juice oz you whatever you
want to call it I'm going to throw in a
little Italian parsley just because I
had it and then it's time to taste first
this straight piece actually let me use
a fork here so I can at least pretend to
be civilized oh yeah that's good but
anyway forget the fork let's get in here
and do this properly what we're really
supposed to be doing here is picking
that sandwich up dipping it in letting
it absorb some of that delicious and
highly flavored broth and we're gonna
eat that just like a classic French dip
dip bite dip bite dip bite so anyway
there you go another one of my
harebrained ideas I tried to combine the
Chicago Italian beef sandwich with the
French Dip sandwich was sort of a little
nod to the pulled pork sandwich and the
final verdict is good sandwich so the
apologies to my friends in Chicago I
really do hope you give that a try head
over to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
